thread.title: Family establishes sudden cardiac arrest research trust after pilot's death
thread.title_full: Family establishes sudden cardiac arrest research trust after pilot's death

author: Patrick Wood
title: Family establishes sudden cardiac arrest research trust after pilot's death
text:
Map: Australia 
Captain Ross Dennerstein was a fit and active family man who was regularly put through the medical tests that all commercial airline pilots are required to undertake — so when he suddenly and unexplainably died at home aged just 47 last October, his family was left reeling. 
Now they want answers. 
"He was highly monitored, all the guidelines were followed ... and yet this happened and has devastated the family," Mr Dennerstein's mother Lorraine told ABC News Breakfast. 
"Since he died there has been another two similar deaths of fathers at my grandson's school. So that's in the last three months." External Link: Ross Dennerstein Trust 
The cause of the father-of-three's death has since been identified as sudden cardiac arrest — something an estimated 15,000 Australians die from each year, including many young people. 
In the face of such personal tragedy, his family has set up the Ross Dennerstein Trust to help fund research into causes and prevention. 
Cardiologist and Baker Heart & Diabetes Institute Associate Professor Andre La Gerche is backing the trust and said far more work was needed in this area of medicine. 
"I think that tragedies such as occurred for Ross and the family are not as uncommon as we think," he said. 
"In the young, under the age of about 35, it is one in 50,000 and becomes far more common through middle age and beyond. 
"This puts it in the same sort of range as issues such as suicide, car accidents, drug use, things for which there is major public health campaigns, whereas this does seem to fly under the radar and is an all-too-common tragedy." 
Dr La Gerche said data from a US registry of sudden death amongst college athletes showed cardiovascular causes represented a similar proportion to suicide and drugs combined and exceeded that due to trauma, including car accidents. 
In Australia, while there is no national registry for causes of sudden death, Dr La Gerche found a comparison of multiple databases suggested a similar picture. 
"There is much more work to be done," he said. 
"We are really on the starting process for what I think could have a big impact." 
For Ms Dennerstein and the rest of the family, establishing the trust in the hopes of helping prevent other deaths is an important part of the grieving process. 
"I think it helps us enormously to know that we might be preventing this happening to other families," she said.
